topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Tanguy and Lenny set up the episode’s focus: the real challenges of building 0→1 products inside a large company. Tanguy previews his 10+ years at Atlassian across multiple bets, including failures and the eventual success of Jira Product Discovery.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Vanta (trust/compliance automation) and WorkOS (enterprise features like SSO/SCIM and authorization via Zanzibar/Warrant).

topics.title: Why 0-to-1 is hard in big companies
topics.summary: Tanguy contrasts big-company advantages (distribution, resources, customer access) with the core challenge: early-stage bets are judged by mature-product metrics and expectations (e.g., MAUs, huge revenue targets). He explains why incubators like Atlassian’s Point A help create breathing room for experimentation.

topics.title: HipChat story: scaling up and rewriting
topics.summary: They unpack HipChat’s rise, Slack’s rapid emergence, and Atlassian’s attempt to “go big,” including the decision to rewrite into Stride. Tanguy shares the emotional impact of shutting down and selling to Slack, and how internal scaling and platform constraints contributed.

topics.title: HipChat lessons: validate assumptions early
topics.summary: Key lesson: don’t assume your existing go-to-market playbook will transfer to a new segment; test distribution and demand early. Tanguy gives a concrete tactic from Jira Product Discovery—running a waitlist/CTA before writing code—to validate reach and interest quickly.

topics.title: HipChat lessons: competition myopia and scarcity
topics.summary: Tanguy warns against feature-chasing competitors and recommends re-anchoring teams on customer interviews and problems. He also explains how big-company over-investment (rewrite + platformization simultaneously) can slow learning, and why startups’ “scarcity” can be an advantage.

topics.title: Statuspage: incident communication and market context
topics.summary: Tanguy describes the DevOps/cloud shift and his exploration of IT operations opportunities for Atlassian. He explains why Statuspage’s simple idea—transparent incident/status communication—reduces chaos during outages and builds customer trust.

topics.title: Statuspage integration: acquisitions are about people
topics.summary: Tanguy shares hard-won lessons integrating a startup into a large org: culture shock, loss of autonomy, new planning horizons, and navigating functional silos and processes. The core insight is that integration challenges are primarily people/process issues, not technology.

topics.title: Acquisition strategy: frankenstack vs acqui-hire
topics.summary: They discuss how acquired products should fit the broader portfolio and platform, including risks of a “frankenstack” (disjoint identity/tech). Tanguy argues for treating acquisitions like hiring—sometimes shutting down the product and rebuilding on the platform to accelerate roadmap—then contrasts this with the different risks of rewriting an already-scaled product.
